question: Given that sand drains water quickly and anything that drains water quickly has little water-holding capacity, which soil component has the least capacity to hold water?

content.source_1: Among the mineral soil separates (sand, silt, clay), water-holding capacity at field capacity follows clay > silt > sand; sand holds the least water because it retains the smallest amount after drainage.
content.source_2: Sand-sized particles have low specific surface area and form large, well-connected macropores, so sandy soils drain rapidly and retain minimal capillary water compared with finer textures.
content.source_3: Under typical conditions, soil organic matter increases water retention because its colloidal surfaces and internal microporosity can absorb and store substantial amounts of water.
content.source_4: High-intensity heating (e.g., during wildfires) can render the organic horizon and organic coatings hydrophobic, causing rainfall to bead and preventing that organic layer from wetting.
content.source_5: Water-repellent organic layers often remain near air-dry even after rain, storing very little water while moisture bypasses via preferential flow or runs off.
content.source_6: By contrast, underlying mineral sands generally still wet and retain some capillary water once infiltration occurs (unless they too are rendered water-repellent by coatings).
